summary: This is an email from Matt McDonald, Managing Editor of The Spectator US, requesting comment on a story about Prince Andrew's correspondence with the Southern District of New York (SDNY). The email contains excerpts from a story by Dominic Green alleging that U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman mischaracterized Prince Andrew's cooperation and breached DOJ rules in his public statements.

persons.name: Matt McDonald
persons.role: Managing Editor of The Spectator US
persons.context: Author of the email requesting comment on a story about Prince Andrew and the SDNY. He is the sender and managing editor.

persons.name: Dominic Green
persons.context: Writer of the story about Prince Andrew's correspondence with the SDNY, excerpts of which are included in the email.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.role: Duke of York, witness in Epstein investigation
persons.context: Subject of the story. His legal team is described as having engaged in email negotiations with the SDNY regarding his witness statement, and he was publicly criticized by Geoffrey Berman.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Publicly denounced Prince Andrew from the steps of Epstein's townhouse, claiming a 'wall of silence.' The story alleges he misled the media and breached DOJ rules.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose crimes are central to the investigation. The document notes the DOJ only approached Prince Andrew after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Her accusations against Prince Andrew, broadcast by the BBC in November 2019, are cited as the trigger for the DOJ's approach to the Prince.

connections.description: Adversarial relationship where Berman, as a prosecutor, publicly criticized Andrew's lack of cooperation, while Andrew's team claims they were negotiating in good faith.
Implied connection as the DOJ sought Andrew as a witness regarding Epstein's crimes. Berman suggested others assisted Epstein.
Giuffre's public accusations against Andrew prompted the DOJ to contact him.
McDonald is the managing editor soliciting comment for Green's story.

events.title: Berman's public denouncement of Prince Andrew
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman denounced Prince Andrew from the steps of Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan townhouse, claiming a 'wall of silence' and 'zero cooperation.'

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died in August 2019. The document states the DOJ only approached Prince Andrew after this event.

events.title: BBC broadcast of Giuffre's accusations
events.description: The BBC broadcast Virginia Roberts Giuffre's accusations against Prince Andrew, which led the DOJ to approach him.

events.title: Andrew's legal team proposes witness statement plan
events.description: Prince Andrew's new legal team suggested drafting a proposal for how he would deliver his witness statement to the DOJ, which the DOJ reportedly accepted.

keyFacts: The story alleges U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman 'actively misled' the media by claiming Prince Andrew provided 'zero cooperation,' while Andrew's team claims to have an email trail proving ongoing negotiations.

The DOJ did not contact Prince Andrew during Jeffrey Epstein's lifetime, only approaching him as a witness after Epstein's death and the BBC's broadcast of Virginia Giuffre's accusations in November 2019.
Prince Andrew's legal team proposed a plan in early January 2020 for how he would deliver a witness statement, which the DOJ accepted.
The story characterizes Berman's public statements implying Andrew aided Epstein's crimes as an 'overt breach' of DOJ rules regarding witness engagement and confidentiality.
Andrew's legal team reportedly refrained from releasing private emails that would prove they were negotiating in good faith, despite Berman's public attack.
